statement.text: Endovascular treatment of PAD includes balloon angioplasty (PTA), stenting, drug-coated balloons (DCB), drug-eluting stents (DES), and atherectomy. Approach selection depends on lesion location, length, calcification, and clinical presentation. Aortoiliac lesions favor stenting while femoropopliteal lesions favor DCB ± atherectomy with spot stenting for flow-limiting dissection.
statement.formal: Endovascular PAD: Aortoiliac = primary stenting; Femoropopliteal = DCB ± atherectomy, spot stent; Infrapopliteal = PTA (no stent), consider DCB; Goal: improve flow for CLI, symptom relief for claudication

explanation.intuition: Endovascular treatment is like unclogging a drain. Angioplasty uses a balloon to push plaque aside. Stents are metal scaffolds that hold the artery open. Drug-coated balloons deliver medication to prevent the artery from re-narrowing. Atherectomy actually removes the plaque like a small drill or vacuum. Different tools work better in different locations - what works in a straight iliac artery may not work in a bending, twisting SFA.
explanation.key_insight: The femoropopliteal segment presents unique challenges due to its length, flexion/extension with movement, and tendency for restenosis. Avoid stenting the entire SFA - use drug-coated balloons as primary therapy with 'spot stenting' only for bailout situations (flow-limiting dissection, significant recoil).
explanation.technical_details: TASC classification guides approach (A/B = endovascular, C/D = open historically, now often endovascular with improved techniques). Drug-coated technology uses paclitaxel to inhibit neointimal hyperplasia. Atherectomy devices include directional (Silverhawk), orbital (Diamondback), laser, and rotational (Rotablator). Covered stents useful for long femoropopliteal lesions (Viabahn).

aortoiliac.technique: Primary stenting preferred (better patency than PTA alone)

femoropopliteal.approach: Endovascular for focal lesions; bypass for long occlusions if good conduit
femoropopliteal.technique: DCB as primary; atherectomy for calcium; avoid routine stenting

infrapopliteal.technique: PTA (balloon only) primary; DCB emerging; stents NOT recommended
infrapopliteal.goal: Establish in-line flow to foot, preferably via angiosome vessel

definition.@value: Catheter-based treatment of peripheral arterial disease using angioplasty, stenting, and other endovascular techniques

clinical_pearls: Iliac arteries: primary stenting = better than PTA alone
SFA: DCB first, spot stent only for bailout - avoid full-length stenting
Tibial arteries: NO stents - PTA ± DCB only
Paclitaxel safety signal noted but FDA concluded benefits outweigh risks
